ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Rachel Mak

Instructor: Nedal Talal Nassar  Rachel Mak actually worked as a TA. And she is great! Very helpful.Nedal was very knowledgeable and also great.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I understand that the class needs to build up slowly because the student body is very mixed (FES-SOM), however, I would rather create workload at the beginning of the semester (when no one is as busy with other classes) in order to speed up the process of getting everyone up to speed regarding business concepts, environmental management and sustainability trends. If everyone works harder at the beginning then everyone can get further by the end without having to work on a paper and a presentation while working on similar heavy stuff for other classes.I find the reading responses useful, do not change that.I would rather make everyone do presentations about what they find regarding their research paper as a midterm evaluation. Perhaps, they need to submit a 10-pager draft before hand in order to get feedback before the presentation (which doesn't have to be exactly at the middle, but one or two weeks after fall break). That way, you have the last half of the class with enough time to work more on the final paper. Perhaps a first draft submission before the end of classes.Why do I think this is better?I think that if you can speed up the process of getting everyone on the same page as early as possible, you can get to the good stuff (the last 5-6 concepts) earlier, and then, you have more time to work on the paper. More time to work on the paper allows for more feedback loops with TAs and Professor, which improves the quality of the final deliverable.A way to speed up the process is by getting rid of the 5/7 case reports and make 4 early case reports mandatory and go for quality over quantity.Too much quantity gets tiresome and dilutes the quality.

At the beginning of the semester, assignments were returned promptly and with good feedback. However, as the semester progressed, we did not receive our papers back in a timely fashion. It took over a month to return our midterm papers, which were returned only after multiple requests during winter break.The field trip was poorly executed and two students were turned away due to their Chinese citizenship.

Question 8: I field trip to Skikorsky was excellent, and I hope it is continued for future students.Question 2: The case studies were an *excellent* method to learn course material, and I believe were more useful than the actual readings.I do emphasize that I would have benefited from more work with At Risk software, including additional lectures and an option to do another assignment similar to the Intriergy case. I found that monte carlo simulation was useful in two other courses I took this semester.

Way too theoretical. I would have liked to see more practical applications: Company A has a problem, how would we fix it? What metrics would we use? What would be your first step? (Rachel Mak interacted this way with the class about her experience at BR and it was the most applied part of the class). We never even discussed what environmental managements systems in corporations were and what they did (besides GE mentioning it in passing).

Very frenetic and uneven assignment schedule, often assignments were due back to back (Monday and Wednesday), then followed by a lull, with a week where nothing was due. This is not conducive to meaningful learning when students are merely rushing to meet seemingly arbitrary deadlines. There was a consensus in the class about the futility of Case #3, which was brushed over in a rushed presentation and in the end to just amounted to mere busy work.

The course is an interesting overview of many Environmental Management tools. It is quite up-to-date, which makes the syllabus interesting. However, it sometimes lacks of depeness in tackling issues.It is well structured but requires over average work between reading requirements, and responces, class assigments and the final paper (considering itÂ´s multiple presentations)

The @Risk case should have had more class time dedicated to its content and software. Nedal should have had more office hours sessions for this case. There were too many overlapping readings and cases assignments. The course would benefit from more depth and focus on particular readings and concepts.The course would be much better if it were smaller (<20 students). Having to work exclusively in groups on writing projects proved frustrating. And in a class in which writing was the only unit of work the instructors put no emphasis on the quality of writing.Also, there was a lot of kool-aid to be drunk in this course. No one questioned the general thesis that corporations are our saviors. Most students expressed shock and indignation at the mention of anti-capitalist or anti-militarist ideas.With all that said, Prof. Chertow is a good lecturer and the course material was interesting.
Much of the class was based on very theoretical content. It was well-taught, but I'm not sure if I can really apply the concepts in the real world

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Subject material. Great for anyone that is studying business and the environment, industrial ecology, etc.
Great content. Great direction. Great speakers. Great Professor.
Materials provided.
Good introduction to corporate environmental management. Case studies were very interesting.
Case studies
An organized way of looking at environmental issues in corporations.
Each case study gave us the opportunity to work with lots of different students on many different topics.
The course was an excellent survey of corporate environmental management and strategy. Prof. Chertow is clearly an expert and it was a pleasure benefiting from her expertise.
Readings and case studies.
Discussions of topics with a wide variety of examples, and follow up ideas and readings based on personal interest
The lectures. The Reinhardt readings were good as were Michael Porter's papers.

The case studies and final group project work provided excellent learning opportunities. Each student had different skills and perspectives to offer and I found I learned a great deal from my classmates. The lectures were also compelling and relevant.
The case assignments were good for putting our reading and lectures into practice.

The conversational style of lectures really enriched the material because students to augment the theoretical concepts with real-world experiences that supported or challenged those concepts. The readings really anchored the discussions well, although it was very hard to stay on top of them in time for classes.
Guest speakers

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Case studies became redundant. Final projects should have been assigned much earlier in the semester.
Why do you need to update the syllabus so many times during the semester?
Less readings so they can actually be accomplished.
It would be very helpful to see the highest graded assignments (case write ups, risk assignment, etc.) so that we can learn how to do them better and improve over the course of the semester.
Clarity on final project. Assignments received in a timely manner.
It took a little while to get comments back on the midterm paper and final presentation, which made it difficult to make timely progress on the final paper.
Making the course more practical.
The reading responses were superfluous in terms of course work. It didn't add much and we already had a significant amount of work that we didn't need the forums.

The case topics and grading could potentially have been improved. The case that was required for all took a tremendous amount of work and I'm not sure it directly aided in the course objectives. Working with risk modeling is interesting and the concept was helpful to learn, but actually learning a tool (@RISK) seemed to be a lot of work that wasn't necessarily additive to the course.

Carefully planning a consistent assignment schedule. Perhaps look at the syllabi of other professors who consistently have an assignment due every class or once a week and do not cluster the deadlines of multiple assignments.
There could be a more clear flow between topics. Concepts appear in isolated ways sometimes, and overall link in the final assigment takes effort and imagination
The TAs and instructors need to engage more with the students, helping them improve their writing.
This is obvious, but the field trip needs to include all students.
The term projects were very inconsistent in success.

Most of the readings were helpful, but they were extremely hard to complete on a regular basis. It might be helpful to separate the readings into required and suggested readings so that students know which ones are the most important for each lecture.
I think that the final paper should be more directly based on the material that we covered in class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very good!
n/a
No discussion/lab section

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Teaching assistants were very knowledgeable and helpful.
Rachel was great, and always very responsive to questions.
Inconsistent grading between teaching assistants.
they were both very helpful!
Both teaching assistants were accessible, organized, timely and engaged.

I thought Nedal was extraordinarily intelligent and knowledgable about the subject matter, but those rapid thought processing capabilities were detrimental during his lecture because he spoke too fast. If he can become a bit more cognizant of how quickly he speaks, that would help his lectures I think. He was a relatively strict grader, which is a strength I believe, although the risk management monte carlo simulation exercise was much more challenging than the others and required a solid skill set to complete in a timely manner. That could be toned down in following years.
I did not have enough interaction with the TA to answer this question

Instructor: Nedal Talal Nassar  My teaching fellow's primary role was to set up and explain the Monte Carlo simulation, which would have been a useful exercise to learn if it weren't for the fact that none of us really knew it was coming. We suddenly were given a run through with no prep in the middle of one class, were told it was due the following week, and then the TF who had the most knowledge about it wasn't accessible for help. Extremely frustrating

Instructor: Nedal Talal Nassar  Nedal is clearly a very smart guy who knows a lot about the subject but we were never told how grading was done and it sometimes felt a little arbitrary. I got the best grades on the assignments I spent the least time on and it felt like in order to get a good grade, we needed to keep repeating things said in answering prior questions. Grading varied greatly between Nedal and Rachel.

Instructor: Nedal Talal Nassar  I personally interacted little with Nedal, but he was of great help in the monte carlo assigment. Discussions both on how to run the simulation software, and the concepts of risk analysis, were very valuable
Instructor: Nedal Talal Nassar  The grading between professors and teaching assistants was inconsistent and lacked some transparency.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provides the foundation for what I plan to do career wise.
Perfect. I'm a joint degree student.
I'm interested in climate change mitigation through the private sector, so there actually isn't a class that fits better into my overall program.

The course was really helpful for me. It has been a really important contribution to my thinking about the work I want to do in the future (international development work that bridges the public and private sectors).
The course was primarily a refresher of working concepts, and an update to some newly way of thinking over classic tools. Most of the course might be applicable for future endeavours
I hope do sustainability strategy work for a private company and perhaps start my own business, so this course is crucial for laying a conceptual foundation on which I will build my career.
This was a key foundational course for my FES objectives. It helped me confirm my interest in the intersection of business and the environment and enabled me to identify areas to study further.
Yes, fits well. I would recommend to anyone going the corporate route.

I never knew how businesses viewed the environment nor what strategies they employed to minimize their footprints. It gave me some solid business concepts, and made me think critically about how effectively business can actually be without government regulation/incentives. I'm honestly not sure how this class fit into my overall program because that's in flux, currently. However, if I continue with industrial ecology or LCA, this fits in perfectly.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take a course with Marian Chertow since I applied to FES. This course is also very applicable to what I would like to do after school.
See #20.
Exposure to business concepts
it fits perfectly with my studies and I had heard great things about marian chertow.

I have a passion for climate change mitigation and have a skill set that positions me well for bridging the public and private sectors, so this course was a perfect way to start thinkingabout linkages in between that interest and my skills/experiences.
To learn about corporate social responsibility.
To update some concepts, and establish networks with the Â¨business and environmentÂ¨community at FES
See above.
Interest in the material and Prof. Chertow's great reputation.

I wanted to see if I would enjoy learning about the relationship between businesses and the environment, especially considering that I've had a lifelong distrust of private corporations, particularly large multinationals. At the beginning of the semester I was thinking about applying to SOM as a joint degree, but I have since changed mymind, but I can still see myself in the private sector.
I'm interested in working in the private sector after graduation and I thought this course would be appropriate to take

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes
As I said, I wish the speed of the course was faster, so that we could cover more stuff.
Yes. I very much enjoyed the course material covered by this class.
Yes, I feel like my knowledge of the corporate world has increased.
I thought the course would contain more practical applications (like the At Risk case study). I would have appreciated opportunities to learn more software programs and other business analysis tools
No. I expected something more applied and this was mostly a theoretical review of literature followed by discussions. The cases were interesting.
it exceeded my expectations.
Yes, definitely.
80% yes
No.
Yes
Somewhat. I would have liked to have heard more countering views on Michael Porter's ideas.
Definitely.
Yes
It did, to some extent. I was hoping to learn a few more skills in this class, but it turned out to be more of a seminar than I had originally imagined.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Coordinating 4-5 peoples' schedules was very challenging. But that's a good lesson in the real world.

I was the only MBA in my group a few times, so I felt that I had to go through work-dynamics learning curve all over again with my FES counterparts. Maybe I should had taken more of a leadership position. But a fairer mix of 50-50 would have been nicer.
Good to complete assignments.

VERY different levels of engagement from first year students and third year joint degrees.You may want to limit 3rd year joint degrees from taking this class. They have no incentive to help with the final project.
Advantages: sharing information. Learning from other group members' experience. Disadvantages: finding time to work together. Some group members were more dedicated to the assignment than others.

If a work group refers to a group project, then yes, I participated in several. They were mostly good, except for one (a case study) where a group member didnot contribute equally and was unresponsive to emails and late to group meetings. The main group project that I worked on was a solid group effort and everyone was equally invested.

Benefits: shared workload made it less stressful at times, especially during heavy workloads from other courses. Learned how organize in groups to complete an assignment well.Disadvantages: Shared workload means inconsistent capabilities and approaches to work assignments. The quality of assignments can decrease dramatically as more people participate in the work group. I also felt that my learning was inhibited in groups because a) if someone in the group understood material XX they were usually the person to work on XX for the assignment and b) This division of labor meant we all focused on one piece of the assignment and had little exposure to the rest of the assignment.

For cases: You are never graded on your own work so you don't know where you stand in terms of learning and group work was not useful because we did not really have time to discuss anything but simply wrote out a designated section of the case.For the final project: Group work was very valuable as we all had different strengths and weaknesses and had enough time to discuss and debate the issues at hand.

some group members didn't pull their own weight on projects which made for an uncomfortable work setting and less productive than it could have been. the positive side is that you get to learn what's it like to work with a diverse group of people, which is a realistic preparation for the real world.

Advantages - You could split the work up and each work on your relative strengths.Disadvantages -It resembled musical chairs, since the groups for weekly assignments were not set for the semester. Juggling the groups for assignments and the final assignment became onerous as the semester progressed.

Assigments were groupal. Groups varied from one task to another, and team dynamics were very dependent on members and backgrounds. The fact that FES and SOM students group contributes to diversity but requires extra scheduling efforts.
Group work helps develop leadership and management skills. It is very frustrating, however, because groups often compromise the quality of work--too many cooks!

There was a lot of group work integrated into this class. Working with groups on the individual cases was challenging at times, in terms of personality differences and coordination challenges, but generally it enhanced learning. Working with a group on the final project was a great experience. We had an excellent group dynamic, that facilitated deep learning and commitment to the project.

The advantages are shared workloads and learning how to work with other people. The disadvantages are that we may have spent more time on logistics than actually discussing the work itself at times, and you don't learn all of the material sometimes (particularly with the final term project).

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a good class taught by a great professor, but don't expect a light workload.
You get out what you put in.
take it.
Decent overview of corporate environmental management, and good reading materials, but fairly disorganized and random in the classroom.
Have a clear vision of how your final project should end and be prepared to work independently.
pick a good final project.
This is a great survey course for the business case (and business considerations in) wise environmental management.

First, read the syllabus very carefully before taking the class. If you are happy with the assignment schedule (ie: the clustering of multiple assignments back to back followed by lulls of inactivity) then ask yourself what you want from an instructor. Although very knowledgeable, Marian was not particularly dynamic, but instead relied heavily on reading directly from the power points, thus taking away from the personal aspect and making it seem rather flat.

It is a difficult course, requiring a sizable time commitment. And don't expect a grade commensurate with your ability or work ethic. Grades reflect arbitrary rubrics or favoritism, depending on the subject.
Prof. Chertow is excellent and the course material is relevant and engaging, especially for students with an interest in the business-environment intersection.
Stay on top of the readings as much as possible.
